7.text:
Thank you, President Schlissel, and to the
Board of Regents. Good morning, everyone!

17.text:
It’s a real honor to be on this great campus
where so much history has been made. And it’s

24.text:
a thrill to walk in the footsteps of Gerald
Ford, James Earl Jones, Lucy Lui, and Tom

31.text:
Brady! I’m told that no quarterback has
played in more Super Bowls than Tom Brady

41.text:
and in case there are any New Yorkers here,
I would just note that he played against the

47.text:
Giants in two of them.
I’m honored to have been asked to speak

103.text:
the faculty, administrators, alumni, and most
of all, to 
the

156.text:
great class of 2016! So, graduates: This is
a great day, but there’s another group here

208.text:
that also deserves a big round of applause:
your parents and families.

218.text:
Of course, there were many other people who
helped you on your journey, so after you receive

240.text:
your diploma, and as you make your way in
the world, remember that your greatest achievements

246.text:
– like today’s – will owe an awful lot
to the people around you.

251.text:
If there’s a secret to success beyond hard
work and good luck, it’s that the more you

258.text:
say ‘we’, and the less you say ‘I’,
the farther you’ll go. It’s something

268.text:
that the most effective leaders understand
and take to heart. Remember: There is almost

274.text:
nothing we do in life that we do alone.
The most useful knowledge that you leave here

281.text:
with today, like the importance of teamwork,
has nothing to do with your major. It’s

287.text:
about how to study, how to cooperate, how
to listen carefully, how to think critically,

294.text:
and how to resolve conflicts through reason.
Those are the most important skills in the

302.text:
working world and it’s why colleges have
always exposed students to challenging and

307.text:
uncomfortable ideas.
The fact that some university boards and administrations

313.text:
now bow to pressure and shield students from
these ideas through ‘safe spaces,’ ‘code

320.text:
words,’ and ‘trigger warnings’ is, in
my view, a terrible mistake. The whole purpose

330.text:
of college is to learn how to deal with difficult
situations – not run away from them.

338.text:
A micro-aggression is exactly that: micro!
But in a macro-sense, one of the most dangerous

347.text:
places on a college campus is a safe space
because it creates the false impression that

355.text:
we can insulate ourselves from those who hold
different views. We can’t – and we shouldn’t

363.text:
try, not in politics, or in the workplace.
In the global economy, and in a democratic

370.text:
society, an open mind is the most valuable
asset you can possess.

375.text:
Today, I’d like to talk a little bit about
why that’s true based on the lessons I’ve

381.text:
learned over the course of my career. Let’s
start with the global economy, and let me

386.text:
put in perspective the job market many of
you are entering. For the first time in human

392.text:
history, the majority of people in the developed
world are being asked to make a living with

397.text:
their minds, rather than their muscles. For
3,000 years, humankind had an economy based

404.text:
on farming: till the soil, plant the seed,
harvest the crop. Hard to do, but fairly easy

412.text:
to learn.
Then, for 300 years, we had an economy based

416.text:
on industry: mold the parts, turn the crank,
assemble the product. Hard to do, but also

424.text:
fairly easy to learn.
Now, we have an economy based on information:

429.text:
acquire the knowledge, apply the analytics,
use your creativity. Hard to do, hard to learn,

439.text:
and even once you’ve mastered it, you’ll
have to start learning all over again, pretty

444.text:
much every day.
If you have the luxury of more than one job

450.text:
offer – now or in the future – don’t
pick the one that pays the most; pick the

456.text:
one that teaches you the most and don’t
worry if the people around you seem quicker

460.text:
or smarter. You can’t control that, but
you can decide that you’re going to outwork

479.text:
them.
In my company, I always give the most complex

483.text:
and important projects to our busiest employees.
Why? Because they are the hardest-working

490.text:
and most dedicated. They’re the first ones
in the office and the last to leave. They’re

495.text:
the ones who take the shortest lunch breaks
and the least vacation. It may not sound like

500.text:
great fun, but in the end, you have to set
your priorities.

507.text:
The secret to success is not rocket science.
It just requires true dedication and a willingness

513.text:
to go the extra mile. Whatever your field,
volunteer to take on new assignments even

526.text:
if they’re outside your comfort zone. Take
the initiative on your own to learn and develop

531.text:
new skills and build contacts who can help
you down the road. When will you have learned

538.text:
enough? Let’s put it this way: I know of
no Nobel Prize winner who has stopped studying.

545.text:
And in the information economy, everyone – in
both white collar and blue collar jobs – will

551.text:
have to keep deepening their knowledge and
adapting to technological change.

575.text:
My life is a perfect example of how important
it is to keep an open mind about careers and

584.text:
technology. After college, I went to business
school in hopes of landing a middle management

589.text:
job in a factory. I had no idea that factories
would soon be closing all across the country,

595.text:
and neither did anyone else.
I ended up finding a job at a Wall Street

599.text:
firm. I loved the job, and soon, my interest
in managing a plant disappeared. I thought

606.text:
I’d stay at the firm forever. And I might
have – except for one small thing: I got

612.text:
fired.
I was 38 years old, and it was a bitter pill

617.text:
to swallow, but it was also the best thing
that ever happened to my career. It led me

623.text:
to start a tech company to computerize real-time
financial data. It sounds simple now, but

628.text:
this was 1981 – the dawn of the computer
age. We were trying to invent a computer that

634.text:
no one wanted with technology that didn’t
exist – a classic example of innovation.

641.text:
Everyone said I was crazy, and maybe they
were right. I had only a limited background

645.text:
in computers, and I had never started or run
a company, but with a lot of help from some

649.text:
very talented and driven people, we succeeded
beyond our wildest dreams.

655.text:
So the lesson is: Whatever you think your
dream job is today, don’t get too attached

660.text:
to it. Chances are, if the job still exists
in 15 years, it will be very different – and

666.text:
you may have found other passions. Keeping
an open mind to new ideas will be essential

671.text:
to your professional success, and it will
be just as crucial to our collective future

676.text:
as a democratic society.
That’s the other lesson I’ve learned that

680.text:
I’d like to share with you today. During
the 12 years I had the honor of serving as

685.text:
Mayor of New York City, I witnessed a disturbing
change in the nature of American politics:

694.text:
a rise in extreme partisanship and intolerance
for other views.

699.text:
I’m a political independent, but over the
course of my life, for non-ideological reasons,

704.text:
I’ve been a Republican and a Democrat. So
I can tell you: Neither party has a monopoly

711.text:
on good ideas; each demonizes the other unfairly
and dishonestly. This is not a new phenomenon

719.text:
– but it has reached a dangerous new level.
In 1796, George Washington spent much of his

726.text:
farewell address warning Americans against
political parties, which he called ‘the

732.text:
worst enemy’ of democratic governments.
He wrote of the natural tendency parties have

738.text:
to elevate a single leader who seeks power,
in his words, ‘on the ruins of public liberty.’

745.text:
In this political season, it’s worth remembering
what Washington had to say. And so, allow

750.text:
me to read a brief passage from his farewell
address.

754.text:
Partisanship, Washington wrote, ‘serves
always to distract the Public Councils, and

761.text:
enfeeble the Public Administration. It agitates
the Community with ill-founded jealousies

767.text:
and false alarms; kindles the animosity of
one part against another, and foments occasionally

774.text:
riot and insurrection… A fire not to be
quenched, it demands a uniform vigilance to

781.text:
prevent its bursting into a flame… lest,
instead of warming, it should consume.’

787.text:
Well said, George. We have survived more than
200 years of political parties largely because

796.text:
the Founding Fathers created checks and balances
to temper the fires of partisanship. Of course,

804.text:
they also excluded most Americans from their
vision of democracy because they feared what

809.text:
democracy might produce. But over the past
two centuries, through the sacrifices of so

815.text:
many civil rights leaders and soldiers, the
promise of equal rights has spread across

820.text:
income, religion, race, gender, and sexual
orientation.

825.text:
We still have a long way to go, and it would
be a mistake to think that our progress is

829.text:
irreversible or that Washington’s warning
is a relic of history. Neither is true and

835.text:
never will be. Democracy and citizenship will
always require constant vigilance against

842.text:
those who fan the flames of partisanship in
ways that consume us and lead to the ruins

848.text:
of public liberty.
We have certainly seen such figures before,

852.text:
in both parties. In the 1930s, there was the
despotic Huey Long in Louisiana, and just

858.text:
a few miles up the road in Dearborn Father
Coughlin blamed ‘Jewish conspirators’

863.text:
for America’s troubles. Then came Charles
Lindbergh in the 40s, Joe McCarthy in the

868.text:
50s, George Wallace in the 60s, and Pat Buchanan
in the 90s.

874.text:
Every generation has had to confront its own
demagogues and every generation has stood

880.text:
up and kept them away from the White House,
at least so far. Now, it’s your turn.

890.text:
In this year’s presidential election, we’ve
seen more demagoguery from both parties than

901.text:
I can remember in my lifetime. Our country
is facing serious and difficult challenges,

907.text:
but rather than offering realistic solutions,
candidates in both parties are blaming our

912.text:
problems on easy targets who breed resentment.
For Republicans, it’s Mexicans here illegally

918.text:
and Muslims, and for Democrats, it’s the
wealthy and Wall Street.

922.text:
The truth is: We cannot solve the problems
we face by blaming anyone. We are all in this

928.text:
together, and we all must be part of the solution.
America’s power in the world comes not from

935.text:
the walls we build, but the doors we open,
and it comes not from tearing down success,

948.text:
but building up opportunity.
American citizenship does not require much

953.text:
of us. We have no military draft; no mandatory
national service; no compulsory voting. Our

960.text:
taxes, compared to Europe, are relatively
low. And yet, our voting rates are terrible,

965.text:
and they’re especially low among young people.
This year, you can help change that.

971.text:
Voting is the only way to stop demagogues.
But the best way to stop demagogues 
from rising in the first place is to elect

988.text:
leaders with the courage to face reality,
make tough decisions, and lead from the front,

993.text:
rather than following from behind. That has
become harder over time. Let me share a story

1000.text:
from my time in City Hall that illustrates
why.

1003.text:
In 2002, we banned smoking in New York City’s
bars and restaurants, and it caused a huge

1008.text:
backlash. We got a lot of angry letters and
phone calls, and I got a lot of one-fingered

1013.text:
waves when I walked down the street. But as
time went by, the ban proved to be a huge

1019.text:
boon to the bar and restaurant business – surprise,
surprise – and smoking rates in our city

1025.text:
went down by nearly 30 percent, helping to
increase life expectancy for New Yorkers two

1029.text:
years above the national average. In fact,
I’m glad to say, the policy became so popular

1036.text:
that cities and states all over the world
copied it.

1039.text:
Today, elected officials who decide to support
a controversial policy will also get angry

1044.text:
letters, phone calls, and faxes, if they still
have fax machines. And for sure, they will

1050.text:
now get millions of angry Tweets and Facebook
posts denouncing them in the harshest possible

1055.text:
terms. That’s democracy in action. But that
kind of instant condemnation also makes some

1062.text:
elected officials afraid to do things that,
in their heart of hearts, they know are right.

1068.text:
So democracy in action can actually produce
a lot of inaction, which we see every day

1073.text:
in Washington, D.C., and other levels of government,
too. When governments fail to address the

1078.text:
needs of the people, voters in both parties
get angry and some politicians exploit that

1084.text:
anger by offering scapegoats instead of solutions.
If we want to stop demagogues, we have to

1089.text:
start governing again, and that requires us
to be more civil; to support politicians who

1095.text:
have the courage to take risks; and to reward
those who reach across the aisle in search

1099.text:
of compromise.
Now I know doing this won’t be easy, and

1103.text:
that’s partly because it’s not just social
media that has changed the civic dialogue.

1107.text:
The constant bombardment of news that we see
on our phones, computers, and TVs gives us

1113.text:
the impression we are acquiring knowledge.
Yet many of the sources, facts, and interpretations

1120.text:
are either dubious, or colored by partisanship,
or outright lies. I say that as the owner

1126.text:
of a media company who has seen how the marketplace
has shifted. Today, people choose cable TV

1132.text:
channels and websites that affirm their own
political beliefs rather than ones that inform

1137.text:
and challenge their beliefs. As a result,
we have grown more politically cloistered

1142.text:
and more intolerant of those who hold different
opinions.

1147.text:
Think about this: In 1960, only four to five
percent of Democrats and Republicans said

1152.text:
they would be upset if a member of their family
married someone from the opposing party. In

1158.text:
2010, one in three Democrats, and one in two
Republicans, said they would disapprove of

1164.text:
such a marriage. In 1960, most people would
never have believed that inter-party marriage

1171.text:
would attract such resistance, while inter-racial
marriage and same-sex marriage would gain

1176.text:
such acceptance. For all the progress we have
made on cultural tolerance, when it comes

1181.text:
to political tolerance, we are moving in the
wrong direction.

1185.text:
We see this trend of political intolerance
across the country: At campaign rallies that

1190.text:
turn violent; on social media threads that
turn vitriolic; and even on college campuses,

1196.text:
where students and faculty have attempted
to censor political opponents.

1201.text:
I know that one of today’s graduates, Omar
Mahmood, has faced threats and intimidation

1206.text:
because he dared to write political satire
about being left-handed in the Michigan Daily

1212.text:
and he refused to apologize for it. Omar,
wherever you are out there, I’m glad you

1217.text:
stood your ground.
Never be afraid to stand up for what you believe

1227.text:
is right, no matter how unpopular it may be
or how many people try to shout you down.

1233.text:
And just as importantly: Never hesitate to
stand up for the rights of others to express

1238.text:
their views and exercise their rights, no
matter how unpopular that may be. The only

1244.text:
way to ensure your right to express yourself
is to protect others’ rights to express

1250.text:
themselves.
In 2010, I found myself in the middle of a

1255.text:
huge debate over free expression. There was
a national uproar over a proposal to build

1260.text:
a mosque several blocks from the World Trade
Center. Members of both parties attacked the

1265.text:
plan as an affront to the victims of the 9/11
attacks. Even the Anti-Defamation League,

1270.text:
whose mission is to protect against religious
discrimination, opposed the idea. But they

1276.text:
had all forgotten: the terrorists didn’t
just attack buildings, they attacked our freedom

1282.text:
to live and pray as we choose according to
our own beliefs and values, equally.

1289.text:
The torch that Lady Liberty holds aloft in
the New York Harbor lights the way for people

1294.text:
of every faith and philosophy, and it shines
down on every corner of the city and every

1300.text:
community across this great land. No religion
should ever face special restrictions on their

1306.text:
rights, whether it concerns building a house
of worship or getting a visa.

1311.text:
As durable as 
the American system of government has been,
democracy is fragile – and demagogues are

1323.text:
always lurking. When Ben Franklin was leaving
the Constitutional Convention, a woman approached

1330.text:
him and asked him: ‘Well, doctor – what
have we got: a republic or a monarchy?’

1336.text:
Franklin replied, ‘A republic – if you
can keep it.’

1340.text:
Well, graduates: It is now your responsibility
to keep it. That starts with keeping an open

1346.text:
mind, voting, and demanding that politicians
offer practical solutions, not scapegoats

1352.text:
or pie-in-the-sky promises. In 1928, Republicans
promised ‘a chicken in every pot and a car

1359.text:
in every backyard.’ They won control of
Congress and the White House – and a year

1365.text:
later, instead of a chicken and a car, we
got the Great Depression.

1368.text:
Today, when a populist candidate promises
free college, free health care, and a pony,

1376.text:
or another candidate promises to make other
countries pay for our needs – remember:

1382.text:
those who promise you a free lunch will invariably
eat you for breakfast. If there were simple

1397.text:
solutions to complex problems, we wouldn’t
have those problems.

1401.text:
I’m optimistic that you graduates will rise
to the occasion and help protect our Republic

1407.text:
against the dangers of demagogues and the
fires of partisanship that Washington warned

1412.text:
us about 220 years ago. I believe in you.
I support you. And I will stand with you in

1418.text:
this battle to the end of my days so that
my children and grandchildren can be as proud

1424.text:
of America’s devotion to freedom and equality
as I am.

1428.text:
As for today: this is a day of celebration,
so relish it; enjoy every minute.
